questions.text: A 65-year-old smoker, male presented with painless hematuria. On further investigation he is diagnosed with bladder cancer extending upto the muscle layer. What should be the treatment of choice in this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radical cystectomy

 

Radical cystectomy is the treatment of choice for a patient with bladder cancer involving the muscle layer.

 

Radical Cystectomy (Option C):

 

  • This is a surgery to remove the entire bladder and possibly nearby tissues and organs. For men, this often includes the prostate and seminal vesicles. For women, the uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes, and part of the vagina might be removed.
  • It is the treatment of choice for muscle-invasive bladder cancer, meaning the tumor has grown into the muscular wall of the bladder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravesical BCG followed by chemotherapy:

 

  • BCG is a type of immunotherapy where Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (a bacterium similar to the one that causes tuberculosis) is introduced directly into the bladder. This stimulates an immune response against cancer cells.
  • This treatment is typically reserved for non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer or carcinoma in situ (CIS).

 

Option B. Systemic Chemotherapy:

 

  • This might be used before surgery to shrink the tumor or after surgery to kill any remaining cancer cells.
  • Systemic chemotherapy alone is not the primary treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer but can be used in conjunction with surgery or other treatments.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy:

 

  • This uses high-energy radiation to kill cancer cells. It might be used as a primary treatment for those who aren't candidates for surgery or combined with chemotherapy as an alternative to surgery.
  • However, the gold standard treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer remains radical cystectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radical cystectomy is the treatment of choice for muscle-invasive bladder cancer

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. An abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of multiple gallstones with no evidence of wall thickening. The bile duct (BD) diameter is measured at 12 mm, and serum bilirubin levels are mildly elevated at 0.8. The patient's alkaline phosphatase levels are significantly elevated at 380, and the gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) levels are raised by 5 times. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MRCP

 

Given the patient's presentation of multiple gallstones, an enlarged bile duct diameter, and elevated liver enzymes, there is a high suspicion of choledocholithiasis (stones in the common bile duct). An MRCP is the most appropriate initial investigation to visualize and confirm the presence of common bile duct stones without subjecting the patient to an invasive procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography): ERCP is an invasive procedure that allows both the visualization and treatment of biliary and pancreatic duct abnormalities. While it can be used to diagnose and treat choledocholithiasis, it is generally reserved for therapeutic interventions after the diagnosis has been established, given the risks associated with the procedure.

 

Option C. Endoscopic ultrasound: This technique can be very sensitive for detecting common bile duct stones and other biliary pathologies. However, in the context of a patient with an enlarged bile duct and elevated liver enzymes suggestive of choledocholithiasis, MRCP would be the preferred initial diagnostic tool.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy: While the patient may ultimately require a cholecystectomy, especially if the gallstones are the cause of her symptoms, it's crucial to first assess and manage any potential common bile duct stones. Directly proceeding to cholecystectomy without addressing potential common bile duct stones could lead to complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, given the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggesting the presence of common bile duct stones, an MRCP is the most appropriate initial step to visualize the biliary system and confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following incisions is used for Appendicectomy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grid iron incision

 

The grid iron incision, also known as the McArthur incision, is the preferred surgical approach for an appendectomy. This incision is made at the McBurney point, which is located one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. The incision is muscle-splitting rather than cutting, which helps in minimizing muscle damage and promotes quicker recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kocher's incision: This is used for open cholecystectomy. It is a right subcostal incision, typically employed for gallbladder surgeries.

 

Option B. Morris incision: This is a flank incision used for accessing the retroperitoneal space, typically for renal surgeries.

 

Option D. Pfannensteil incision: This is a lower abdominal, transverse suprapubic incision often used for gynecological surgeries, such as cesarean sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The grid iron (McArthur) incision is the standard incision used for appendectomy, made at the McBurney point and characterized by a muscle-splitting approach.

questions.text: Following a stab injury to the chest, the following imaging finding was noted. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemothorax

 

In this scenario, the patient has sustained a stab injury to the chest, and an X-ray has been provided as part of the diagnostic process. The X-ray described in the  reveals a white area on the affected side of the lung field.

Hemothorax: A hemothorax occurs when blood accumulates in the pleural cavity. On a chest X-ray, this condition presents as a white-out or opaque area on the affected side due to the fluid (blood) collecting in the pleural space. The clinical findings, such as hypotension (which can result from blood loss), further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: In contrast, a pneumothorax, which is the presence of air in the pleural space, would show up on a chest X-ray as a black area (radiolucency) without lung markings, indicating air in the pleural space. This would not match the white-out appearance seen in the provided X-ray.

 

Option C. Diaphragmatic Rupture: This condition would typically present with air-fluid levels within the chest cavity if abdominal organs have herniated into the thoracic cavity. However, this is not indicated by the described X-ray findings.

 

Option D. Lung Contusion: A lung contusion would appear as a focal area of consolidation (white patch) due to localized bleeding or bruising of the lung tissue, but it would not cause a widespread white-out of the lung field.

 

Thus, the presence of a white-out on the X-ray, along with clinical signs such as hypotension, suggests the correct diagnosis is hemothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A white-out on the chest X-ray after a chest injury, especially with accompanying hypotension, is indicative of a hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space.

questions.text: All of the following are considered premalignant conditions of the stomach, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hiatus hernia

 

Explanation:

 

Premalignant conditions of the stomach are pathological changes that increase the risk of developing gastric cancer. Among the options given, hiatus hernia does not carry a significant increased risk of gastric malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric ulcer - TRUE premalignant condition. Gastric ulcers have malignant potential, unlike duodenal ulcers. Chronic gastric ulcers may undergo malignant transformation, which is why multiple biopsies are recommended for all gastric ulcers to exclude malignancy.

 

Option B. Pernicious anemia and achlorhydria - TRUE premalignant condition. Autoimmune gastritis leads to parietal cell destruction, causing achlorhydria and intrinsic factor deficiency (leading to pernicious anemia). Patients with pernicious anemia have a 2-3 times increased risk of developing gastric cancer.

 

Option D. Atrophic gastritis - TRUE premalignant condition. Atrophic gastritis, particularly when associated with intestinal metaplasia, is a well-established precursor to gastric cancer. Chronic atrophic gastritis leads to loss of gastric glands and development of intestinal metaplasia, which can progress to dysplasia and cancer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While gastric ulcers, pernicious anemia with achlorhydria, and atrophic gastritis are established premalignant conditions that increase the risk of gastric cancer, hiatus hernia is a structural abnormality that is not directly associated with increased malignant potential in the stomach.

questions.text: Obturator Sign in Acute Appendicitis is most commonly associated with which appendix position? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Pelvic Appendix

 

Explanation:

 

The obturator sign is elicited when the examiner flexes the patient's right hip and knee and then internally rotates the hip, causing pain in the hypogastrium. This sign is positive when an inflamed appendix lies in contact with the obturator internus muscle. The pelvic position of the appendix places it directly adjacent to the obturator internus muscle, making this sign characteristic of pelvic appendicitis. When the obturator muscle contracts during internal rotation of the hip, it irritates the inflamed appendix, producing pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retrocecal - This position places the appendix behind the cecum against the psoas muscle, typically resulting in a positive psoas sign (pain on extension of the hip) rather than obturator sign. Retrocecal appendicitis often presents with flank or back pain.

 

Option C. Pre-Ileal - When the appendix lies anterior to the terminal ileum, it typically produces classic right lower quadrant pain at McBurney's point without specific muscle signs.

 

Option D. Post-Ileal - In this position, the appendix lies behind the ileum but not necessarily in contact with the obturator muscle, making the obturator sign unlikely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The obturator sign indicates irritation of the obturator internus muscle by an inflamed appendix, most commonly occurring when the appendix is in the pelvic position, and serves as an important physical examination finding for identifying atypical appendicitis.

choices.text: IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, assisted drainage, and MRI
IV fluids, MRI, assisted drainage, and laparotomy
IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage
IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, assisted drainage, MRI, and laparotomy

questions.text: Which of the following steps are included in the management of acute necrotizing pancreatitis in a patient with large intra-abdominal fluid accumulation and pancreatic necrosis?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage

 

MRI is not indicated in patients with acute necrotising pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct steps in the management of acute necrotizing pancreatitis include IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage. Large intra-abdominal fluid accumulation and pancreatic necrosis are complications of acute pancreatitis that require immediate management.

 

Aggressive fluid resuscitation, pain control, and early nutrition are initiated, followed by contrast-enhanced computed tomography to diagnose necrosis. If infected necrosis is suspected, fine-needle aspiration is done, and the aspirate is subjected to Gram staining and culture sensitivity. IV antibiotics are started with carbapenem as the first-choice drug.

 

The step-up approach, which includes percutaneous drainage followed by minimally invasive video-assisted retroperitoneal debridement, is adopted for definitive management. Hence, the correct option is C) IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male pt presented to your clinic with persistent non-pitting edema in their lower extremities as shown below. What could be the most likely reason for this symptom? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the likeliest cause.
  • It involves the build-up of protein-rich fluid in tissue interstitial spaces.
  • It shows typical “non-pitting” edema in the second stage of lymphedema.
  • Filariasis is the most common etiology.
  • In severe and long standing cases, skin changes are seen giving the limb an appearance of “Elephantiasis”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arterial Disorders: Arterial disorders may lead to symptoms such as leg pain, intermittent claudication, and tissue damage due to reduced blood supply. Edema is uncommon.

 

Option C. Venous Disorders: These disorders can encompass conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT), varicose veins, chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), and venous ulcers. Venous disorders may result in symptoms like leg swelling, pain, and skin changes, and they can vary in severity. No evidence of skin changes associated with varicose veins are seen.

 

Option D. Coronary Heart Disease: Coronary heart disease (CHD), also known as coronary artery disease (CAD), is a common heart condition where the coronary arteries that supply blood to the heart muscle become narrowed or blocked due to the buildup of fatty deposits (atherosclerosis). CAD may lead to heart failure leading to bilateral lower limb pitting edema, which is not seen in the case above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphedema is characterized by non-pitting edema due to the accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the tissue interstitial spaces. It can lead to significant swelling and skin changes, particularly in the lower extremities, distinguishing it from other causes of edema.

questions.text: Image of a patient with large ulcerated breast cancer with liver metastasis. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Simple mastectomy

 

The patient in the image has a large ulcerated breast tumor with confirmed liver metastasis, classifying the cancer as stage IV (T4, M1). In cases of stage IV breast cancer with distant metastasis, the primary goal of management shifts from curative to palliative care, focusing on improving quality of life and managing symptoms.

For patients with large ulcerated tumors, palliative simple mastectomy may be considered to alleviate symptoms like pain, ulceration, discharge, or infection, which can significantly impact the patient’s quality of life. This procedure is not intended to cure but to provide local control of the tumor and improve comfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRM (Modified Radical Mastectomy): This is a more aggressive surgical approach that involves removal of the breast tissue along with axillary lymph nodes. It is typically reserved for curative intent in earlier stages of breast cancer without distant metastasis. It is not appropriate for palliation in stage IV disease with liver metastasis.

 

Option C. Radical mastectomy: This involves removal of the entire breast, underlying chest muscles, and axillary lymph nodes. This extensive procedure is rarely performed today and is not suitable for palliative care in metastatic disease due to its high morbidity without a survival benefit.

 

Option D. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is used in locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) to shrink tumors before surgery, but in the presence of distant metastasis (M1), systemic chemotherapy alone would be preferred for palliative purposes. Surgery would only follow if there was a significant symptomatic tumor burden requiring local control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with stage IV breast cancer with distant metastasis, such as liver metastasis, the primary focus is on palliation. Simple mastectomy may be performed to manage symptoms from a large ulcerated tumor, but more extensive surgeries or curative approaches are not indicated.

questions.text: A teenage patient came with pain and a palpable lump in Right iliac fossa. Blood investigation shows increased TLC. What is the management? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oschner Sherren regime

 

The patient, a teenager, presents with pain and a palpable lump in the right iliac fossa (RIF), along with an increased total leukocyte count (TLC). These findings are suggestive of acute appendicitis with an appendicular phlegmon. An appendicular phlegmon occurs when inflammation spreads, and the omentum and other structures seal off the inflamed appendix, forming a palpable mass.

 

In this scenario, immediate surgical intervention such as laparoscopy or open appendectomy is not recommended because it involves breaking the seal formed by the omentum, complicating the procedure. Instead, the preferred management is conservative, following the Oschner Sherren regime. This regimen involves:

 

  • Keeping the patient nil by mouth (NPO).
  • Administering intravenous antibiotics to control infection.
  • Providing intravenous fluids for hydration.
  • Observing the patient until the inflammation subsides.

 

Once the lump resolves and the infection is under control, an interval appendectomy can be performed later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopy Appendectomy: This is not recommended in the presence of an appendicular phlegmon.

 

Option C. Alvarado regime: This is a scoring system used to assess the likelihood of appendicitis, not a management strategy.

 

Option D. Open Appendectomy: This is not recommended when a phlegmon is present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Oschner Sherren regime is the conservative management approach for an appendicular phlegmon, involving NPO status, IV antibiotics, and fluids, followed by interval appendectomy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. Upon examination, it is found that the patient is unable to pass urine and there is visible blood at the meatus. A retrograde urethrogram was performed as shown below. What is the most likely site of urethral injury? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Membranous urethra

 

  • Given the presentation of the patient - specifically the inability to pass urine, visible blood at the meatus after a motor vehicle accident and the RGU appearance - the membranous urethra is the most likely site of injury.
  • This is because it's closely associated with pelvic fractures, which are common in such accidents.
  • The management includes a retrograde urethrogram to confirm the injury, followed by the insertion of a suprapubic catheter to bypass the injured segment and allow for healing.
  • Membranous urethral rupture is typically associated with pelvic fractures and presents with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and a high-riding prostate on digital examination.
  • Bruising may also be visible over the pubic area, scrotum, and penis. Urine extravasates in the perivesical space.
  • The membranous urethra is the shortest and narrowest part of the male urethra and passes through the urogenital diaphragm.
  • This segment is particularly vulnerable in cases of pelvic fractures, often seen in motor vehicle accidents.
  • Clinical features, such as blood at the meatus and urinary retention as seen in the case, often point to an injury in this region.
  • On rectal examination, a high-riding prostate may be palpated, indicating disruption of the urethra below the prostate. This choice aligns with the given scenario and is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulbar Urethra: It's a common site of injury due to straddle injuries (like falling onto a bicycle crossbar) because of its exposed location. It would typically result in a perineal hematoma.

 

Option B. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: This occurs due to a blow to the pelvis; however, no blood is seen at the urethral meatus.

 

Option D. Penile Urethra: This portion is within the shaft of the penis, encased within the corpus spongiosum. Trauma to the penile urethra usually results from direct trauma to the penis, such as in the context of a penile fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Membranous urethral injuries are common in pelvic fractures, presenting with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and possibly a high-riding prostate on rectal examination. Retrograde urethrogram is used for confirmation.

questions.text: Which of the below is the most preferred investigation for parathyroid adenoma localisation? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sestamibi SPECT

 

This is the preferred diagnostic tool for identifying parathyroid adenomas. The technique involves the use of a radioactive tracer, typically Technetium-99m sestamibi, which is absorbed by hyperactive parathyroid tissue more than normal tissue. SPECT provides three-dimensional imaging, improving the localization of hyperactive parathyroid glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT (Computed Tomography): CT scans are not typically the first line of imaging due to the high levels of radiation exposure and the potential need for contrast agents.

 

Option C. Technetium-99m Sestamibi (tech99-Sestamibi) scan: This is a nuclear imaging which uses a gamma camera for imaging.

 

Option D. USG (Ultrasound): Ultrasound is a non-invasive, widely available, and less expensive method to examine the neck for parathyroid adenomas. It is particularly useful in conjunction with Sestamibi scans, as it helps to evaluate the structure of the neck and localize adenomas. However, its effectiveness can be limited by the operator's experience and the patient's anatomy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While all these methods can assist in the diagnosis and localization of parathyroid adenomas, Sestamibi SPECT is generally considered the most effective standalone imaging modality due to its high specificity for active parathyroid tissue and its ability to provide detailed spatial resolution. It is particularly valuable in surgical planning to ensure precise removal of the adenoma.

choices.text: Rest pain is seen more in the night
Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.
The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction

questions.text: Which of the statements regarding claudication pain is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.

 

Intermittent claudication is characterized by muscle pain (ache, cramp, numbness or sense of fatigue), classically in the calf muscle, which occurs during exercise and is relieved by a short period of rest (< 5 minutes). The pain does not typically start with the first step but develops after a predictable distance of walking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rest pain is seen more in the night: True. Rest pain is a more severe symptom of peripheral artery disease (PAD). It typically indicates more advanced disease than intermittent claudication. This pain occurs when the limb is at rest, often at night due to the decreased perfusion that results from the horizontal position of the limb. It often awakens the patient from sleep and can be relieved by hanging the leg over the bed or walking.

 

Option C. Most common cause is atheroma: True. The most common cause of intermittent claudication is atherosclerosis (plaque or atheroma formation) in the peripheral arteries. This reduces blood flow to the muscles during activity, causing pain.

 

Option D. The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction: True. The site of pain (e.g., calf, thigh) does not always directly correlate with the level of arterial obstruction. For instance, while calf pain is often due to femoropopliteal disease, it can also be caused by aortoiliac disease. However, the location of claudication pain can provide a clue to the level of disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorrect statement among the provided options is that pain in intermittent claudication occurs at the first step of walking.

questions.text: Long lasting results in CABG are obtained when graft is harvested from which blood vessel? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal mammary artery

 

Natural arterial grafts last longer than venous or synthetic grafts. The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) is the most preferred vascular graft for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) due to its superior long-term patency rates. This is because the LIMA has a muscular wall that resists atherosclerosis, making it more durable and less prone to occlusion compared to other grafts.

 

Internal mammary artery:

 

  • Location: Runs along the inside of the chest wall.
  • Benefits: The LIMA is often used in CABG because of its proximity to the heart and its superior long-term patency rates. It has a muscular wall that resists atherosclerosis, ensuring longer-lasting results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long saphenous vein:

 

  • Usage: Commonly used due to its length, making it suitable for multiple grafts.
  • Longevity: Vein grafts tend to have higher rates of occlusion over time compared to arterial grafts. They do not have the same durability as arterial grafts and are more prone to developing atherosclerosis.

 

Option C. Poly tetra fluoroethyl:

 

  • Material: Synthetic graft.
  • Usage: Synthetic grafts are generally not the first choice for CABG due to concerns about patency and the risk of complications compared to natural grafts. They are less favored due to a higher risk of thrombosis and occlusion.

 

Option D. Gastroepiploic artery:

 

  • Usage: Less commonly used than the IMA or saphenous vein.
  • Indication: Typically reserved for situations where other preferred graft sources are not available or viable. Its long-term patency rates are not as favorable as the LIMA.

 

Arterial grafts, like the LIMA, are preferred over venous grafts because they have non-collapsible lumens, reducing the risk of thrombosis and occlusion, and providing better long-term outcomes in CABG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) is the preferred graft for CABG due to its superior long-term patency rates and resistance to atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented in OPD with a swelling that has been slowly growing in the past 2 years. On examination, it was variable in consistency and mobile. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid tumor

 

  • The given clinical scenario and image points to a diagnosis of parotid tumor.
  • MC benign parotid tumor is Pleomorphic Adenoma.
  • MC site: superficial lobe of parotid

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst: Seen in children at lines of mesodermal fusion like outer canthus of eye.

 

 

Option C. Sebaceous cyst: Will show soft consistency and punctum.

 

 

Option D. Swollen cervical lymph node – will show firm consistency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A parotid tumor, particularly pleomorphic adenoma, is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland.
  • It is characterized by slow growth, a variable consistency, and mobility, commonly found in the superficial lobe of the parotid gland.
  • Proper diagnosis involves imaging and FNAC, with treatment typically involving surgical removal while preserving the facial nerve if possible.

questions.text: Based on the given image, calculate the total percentage of body surface area affected. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20-30%

 

Explanation:

 

To calculate burn surface area in this scenario:

 

  • Image shows only anterior burns (no posterior burns mentioned)
  • Total anterior surface = 50% of body surface area

 

Areas involved:

 

  • Half of face and neck (~1%)
  • Partial chest and abdomen (~13-14%)
  • Parts of upper limb (~4-5%)
  • Parts of thigh (~4-5%)

 

Approximate calculation:

 

  • About half of anterior surface is burned
  • Half of 50% = ~25%
  • Therefore, the total burn area falls in 20-30% range

 

While Lund and Browder charts are more accurate for children, this approximation method gives similar results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10-20%: Incorrect as burns involve significant anterior surface area

 

Option C. 40-50%: Incorrect as only anterior burns are present, not circumferential

 

Option D. 60%: Incorrect as this would indicate extensive circumferential burns

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burn surface area is calculated using the Rule of Nines for adults or the Lund and Browder Chart for children. In the given case, the estimated burn area was 20-30%.

questions.text: In a seat belt injury, which of the following organs is most commonly affected? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus 

 

Hollow viscus organs such as the small intestine and colon are more commonly affected in seat belt injuries due to their position and vulnerability to compression forces applied by the seat belt.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver and spleen: While the liver and spleen can be injured in seat belt injuries, they are not the most commonly affected organs.

 

Option B. Duodenum: The duodenum, being relatively protected by its retroperitoneal location, is less commonly affected in seat belt injuries compared to other abdominal organs.

 

Option C. Pancreas: The pancreas, located deep in the abdomen, can be injured in seat belt injuries, but it is not as commonly affected as other organs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In seat belt injuries, hollow viscus organs, particularly the small intestine and colon, are most commonly affected due to their susceptibility to compression forces, emphasizing the importance of thorough evaluation for intra-abdominal injuries.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with symptoms of acute bacterial prostatitis, including fever, chills, dysuria, and perineal pain. A urine sample is taken, and a culture is performed, which reveals the presence of a common organism associated with acute bacterial prostatitis. Identify the organism?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. E. coli

 

Escherichia coli, commonly known as E. coli, is a gram-negative bacillus and is part of the normal flora of the gastrointestinal tract. E. coli is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the vast majority of cases. It's also a very common cause of urinary tract infections in general.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterococcus: Enterococcus species are gram-positive cocci that are part of the normal gut flora. They are an infrequent cause of acute bacterial prostatitis.

 

Option B. Proteus: Proteus species are gram-negative bacilli. They can cause a variety of infections, including urinary tract infections and, less commonly, prostatitis. A characteristic of Proteus infections is the production of urease, which splits urea into ammonia and leads to an alkaline urine that can cause struvite stone formation.

 

Option C. Streptococcus Agalactiae: Also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), Streptococcus agalactiae is a gram-positive coccus. While it's a leading cause of neonatal infections, it's an infrequent cause of urinary tract infections in adults and an even rarer cause of prostatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Escherichia coli (E. coli) is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the majority of cases and is frequently found in urinary tract infections.

questions.text: A patient who is suffering from a pressure sore on examination is found to have partially broken skin with a shallow ulcer. What is the grade of the sore? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

Pressure sore grading:

 

  • Grade 1: Non-blanching erythema with intact skin
  • Grade 2: Partial thickness skin loss involving epidermis/dermis, shallow ulcer
  • Grade 3: Full thickness skin loss with visible subcutaneous fat
  • Grade 4: Full thickness tissue loss with exposed bone/muscle/tendon In this case,  partial skin loss with shallow ulcer indicates Grade 2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade 1:

 

  • Only shows non-blanching erythema
  • Skin remains intact
  • No ulceration present

 

Option C. Grade 3:

 

  • Shows full-thickness skin loss
  • Subcutaneous fat visible
  • Deeper than described in question

 

Option D. Grade 4:

 

  • Represents full thickness tissue loss
  • Exposes deeper structures (bone/muscle/tendon)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grade 2 pressure sore is characterized by partial thickness skin loss with shallow ulceration, without exposure of deeper tissues.

 

Stages:

 

  1. Non blanching erythema with intact skin
  2. Partial thickness skin loss (some skin intact)
  3. Full thickness loss (subcut, Fat seen)
  4. Subcut, Loss (deep fascia/muscles/bones tendons seen)

 

 

Management:

 

  • Avoid continuous supine position → frequent change in position 
  • Use of air mattress/water bed
  • Cover the pressure sore: fascia lata flap/ negative pressure wound therapy (VAC dressing)

questions.text:
A 73-year-old individual arrives with painless rectal bleeding. Which of the listed investigations are conducted for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Colonoscopy
  2. CECT
  3. CEA
  4. CA 19-9
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 3

 

1. Colonoscopy: This is an endoscopic examination of the large bowel and the distal part of the small bowel. It provides a visual diagnosis and can offer biopsy or removal of suspected lesions. It is an essential diagnostic tool for any patient with per-rectal bleeding to identify potential sources such as polyps, tumors, or colitis.

 

2. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography):  CECT can provide detailed cross-sectional images of the body. In the context of rectal bleeding, it might be used to evaluate the extent of a detected tumor, check for metastatic disease, or to view vascular anomalies that might be causing the bleeding, such as arteriovenous malformations.

 

3. CEA (Carcinoembryonic Antigen): CEA is a tumor marker. Its level can be elevated in colorectal cancers as well as other malignancies and conditions. Monitoring the levels of CEA might help in diagnosing, prognosis, and checking the recurrence of colorectal cancers. 

 

Other Option:

 

4. CA 19-9: CA 19-9 is another tumor marker. It is more typically associated with pancreatic cancer. However, its specificity for colorectal cancer is not as high as CEA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the patient's presenting symptom of painless rectal bleeding:

 

  • Colonoscopy is a primary diagnostic tool to visualize and biopsy any potential sources of bleeding.
  • CECT could be useful in determining the extent of a potential tumor or to check for other causes of bleeding.
  • CEA might be used to check for the possibility of colorectal cancer.

 

Hence, the investigations that would be most appropriate and relevant for this patient would be options 1, 2, and 3. Therefore, answer choice D) 1, 2, and 3 is correct.

questions.text:
What investigations would you recommend for a female patient who presents with a 4cm x 3cm irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast and a palpated lymph node of 2cm in the right axilla, but no mass palpated in the opposite breast? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Bilateral Mammography
  2. PET Scan
  3. Biopsy of the breast mass
  4. USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

  • The clinical presentation indicates that the patient may have breast cancer with local spread but no distant metastasis. To further investigate this, it is recommended to conduct bilateral mammography, biopsy of the breast mass (Triple assessment), and USG-guided biopsy of the suspicious lymph node.
  • Diagnostic mammography is a useful tool for examining women with abnormal findings, including breast masses and nipple discharge, and it is more accurate than clinical examination in detecting early breast cancers.
  • Breast cancer can be identified through mammographic features such as a solid mass with or without stellate features, asymmetric thickening of breast tissue, or clustered microcalcifications.
  • To diagnose carcinoma, a core needle biopsy or fine-needle aspiration is usually performed before any treatment begins. In cases where suspicious lymph nodes are present, US-guided fine-needle aspiration or core biopsy is performed to determine the presence of metastatic disease.
  • PET scans are typically done after completion of triple assessment and confirmation of malignancy of breast.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with features of chronic pancreatitis with recurrent attacks and has a 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present. Which of the following is the surgery of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

 

  • In the given scenario of dilated pancreatic duct with stones, a drainage procedure in the form of longitudinal pancreatico-jejunostomy (Peusthow) is preferred.
  • CHRONIC PANCREATITIS - Irreversible damage to architecture of pancreas.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple’s procedure): This procedure involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and bile duct. It is typically reserved for malignancies or specific inflammatory conditions localized to the head of the pancreas. It is not the primary choice for diffuse chronic pancreatitis with a dilated duct.

 

Option C. ERCP and sphincterotomy: ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) with sphincterotomy can aid in the removal of pancreatic calculi but is not considered a long-term solution for chronic pancreatitis with a significantly dilated duct.

 

Option D. Coring of the pancreas head: Coring of the pancreatic head may be considered if inflammation is limited to the head of the pancreas alone, but it is not suitable for the diffuse dilation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with chronic pancreatitis and a significantly dilated pancreatic duct (greater than 6 mm), the preferred surgical treatment is longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (Peustow procedure).
  • This procedure helps to relieve ductal hypertension and improve drainage, alleviating pain and other symptoms associated with chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text: What is the angle between the laparoscopic working port and telescope called? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azimuth angle

 

In laparoscopic surgery:

 

  • Azimuth angle: Angle between working port and telescope (15-30 degrees)
  • Essential for ergonomic comfort during surgery
  • Prevents instrument clash with camera
  • Not possible to generate in single incision laparoscopic surgery
  • Inadequate angle leads to difficulty in surgery

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Elevation angle:

 

  • This is the angle between instrument and abdominal wall
  • Refers to vertical orientation of instruments
  • Not related to telescope-port relationship

 

Option C. Working angle:

 

  • Not a standard term in laparoscopic ergonomics
  • No specific angle is defined by this term

 

Option D. Manipulation angle:

 

  • This is the angle between two working ports
  • Refers to the angle between the surgeon's right and left-hand instruments
  • Different from telescope-port relationship

 

Educational Objective:

 

The angle between the laparoscopic working port and telescope is called the Azimuth angle, which should ideally be 15-30 degrees for optimal ergonomics.

choices.text: Antibiotics and follow-up after 3days
Incision and Drainage
Empty the breasts every 3 hours

questions.text: A 3-day postpartum mother comes in the hospital with history of pain, red, fluctuant, 2 cm mass in the breast. USG shows fluid collection. What will you do in the management of this patient? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incision and Drainage

 

The described case scenario indicates a breast abscess, which commonly occurs in lactating women and presents with pain, tenderness, and a fluctuant swelling. The most common causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus. The treatment of choice for a breast abscess, especially when a fluid collection is confirmed via ultrasound (USG), is incision and drainage (I&D). This procedure involves making an incision to allow the pus to drain, thereby relieving pain and reducing the infection. Antibiotics, such as cloxacillin, are typically prescribed post-procedure to treat the underlying bacterial infection.

 

Updated management from Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition:

 

  • Small abscesses (<3 cm, <30 cc volume): Aspiration + antibiotics
  • Large abscesses (>3 cm, >30 cc volume): Suction catheter drainage

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Antibiotics and follow-up after 3 days:
    • Antibiotics are essential to treat the infection, but in the presence of a fluctuant mass suggesting pus, they are not sufficient on their own. Without drainage, the abscess is unlikely to resolve and may worsen.
  • Option C. Hot fomentation:
    • Hot fomentation can provide symptomatic relief by reducing pain and promoting drainage. However, it is not a definitive treatment for an established abscess and should be used as supportive care alongside I&D.
  • Option D. Empty the breasts every 3 hours:
    • Regular emptying of the breasts is crucial for preventing milk stasis, which can lead to mastitis and abscess formation. While this practice is beneficial for preventing complications, it does not address an existing abscess. Proper drainage of the abscess is necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a lactating mother with a confirmed breast abscess, the definitive treatment is incision and drainage to alleviate pain and resolve the infection.

choices.text: Incontinence when patient lies down and coughs

questions.text: A 37-year-old male comes with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS). Which of the following is not a typical presenting LUTS? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Incontinence during intercourse

 

While urinary incontinence during intercourse can occur, it is not considered a typical lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS). LUTS typically encompasses symptoms related to storage and voiding of urine. Incontinence during intercourse might be related to other causes, including psychological factors, or specific conditions impacting the pelvic floor, but it's not a routine symptom when discussing LUTS.

 

Incontinence during sexual activity is not considered a lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sudden urge to urinate: This symptom is known as urgency and is a common lower urinary tract symptom. It is the sudden and strong desire to urinate, which can be difficult to delay.

 

Option B. Incontinence while asleep: This is referred to as nocturnal enuresis or bedwetting. It is a type of urinary incontinence where the patient involuntarily releases urine during sleep. This can be a symptom associated with a variety of conditions, including bladder issues, sleep disorders, or even psychological factors.

 

Option C. Incontinence when a patient lies down and coughs: This is known as stress incontinence. It occurs when physical movement or activity, such as coughing, sneezing, running, or heavy lifting, puts pressure (stress) on the bladder, causing unintentional urine leakage. It's often due to weakened pelvic floor muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LUTS can be divided into three categories: storage, voiding, and post-micturitional.

 

Storage LUTS involves the failure of the bladder to act as a urine reservoir, leading to symptoms such as increased frequency of voiding, nocturia, urgency, and urge incontinence.

 

Voiding LUTS is commonly seen in bladder outlet obstruction and includes symptoms such as hesitancy, reduced stream, and straining.

 

Post-micturitional LUTS, also caused by bladder outlet obstruction, includes symptoms such as incomplete emptying and post-micturition dribble. Other symptoms of LUTS include stress incontinence, nocturnal enuresis, and strangury.

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady presents with mobile breast lump which feels like a mouse in breast. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibroadenoma

 

A fibroadenoma, often referred to as a "breast mouse," is a benign breast tumor commonly seen in young women between the ages of 16-25. It is characterized by a painless, slowly growing, solitary mobile lump that feels rubbery and can easily move under the skin. This mobility is why it is described as feeling like a "mouse" in the breast.

 

Fibroadenoma:

 

  • Commonality: A benign breast tumor commonly seen in young women.
  • Features: Described as rubbery and mobile under the skin, hence the term "breast mouse."
  • Age Group: Typically affects young women between 16-25 years of age.
  • Diagnosis Fit: Given the patient's age and the description of the lump, fibroadenoma is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phyllodes tumor:

 

  • Nature: Rare breast tumors that can be benign, borderline, or malignant.
  • Growth: They tend to grow rapidly and can become quite large.
  • Age Group: They typically occur in women after the age of 40.
  • Distinguishing Feature: Rapid growth and potential to become large differentiate it from a fibroadenoma.

 

Option C. Invasive ductal carcinoma:

 

  • Nature: The most common type of breast cancer.
  • Presentation: Begins in the ducts and invades nearby tissues in the breast.
  • Mobility: Less likely to be as mobile or rubbery as a fibroadenoma.
  • Age Group: While it can occur in younger women, the mobility and description of the lump make this less likely.

 

Option D. Breast abscess:

 

  • Nature: A pocket of pus due to bacterial infection.
  • Symptoms: Associated with inflammation, redness, warmth, and tenderness.
  • Presentation: Would not be described as mobile or rubbery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibroadenomas are common, benign breast tumors in young women, characterized by a mobile, rubbery lump that can easily move under the skin, often described as feeling like a "mouse" in the breast.

choices.text: Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. On examination, he is noted to have subcutaneous emphysema and decreased breath sounds on the right side. His vital signs are unstable. What is the immediate management for this patient?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

 

  • The clinical scenario of no air entry on the right side and unstable vitals suggests tension pneumothorax.
  • Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased intrathoracic pressure.
  •  This pressure can shift the mediastinum, compromise venous return to the heart, and result in hypotension or shock.
  • Immediate needle decompression or needle thoracostomy is necessary, which involves inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line to relieve the trapped air and stabilize the patient.
  • The definitive management is tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.
  • The clinical findings suggest a tension pneumothorax. An immediate decompression is needed to prevent circulatory collapse by allowing trapped air to escape, which can stabilize the patient until a chest tube can be placed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV fluids for resuscitation: While fluid resuscitation is vital in the management of trauma patients, the priority in this scenario, given the clinical findings suggestive of tension pneumothorax, is to relieve the trapped air. While IV fluids can support the circulatory system, they won't address the primary problem, which is the tension pneumothorax. The priority in trauma management follows the Airway -> Breathing -> Circulation (ABC) protocol.

 

Option C. Intubation and positive pressure ventilation: Intubation and positive pressure ventilation can be dangerous in a patient with tension pneumothorax. Positive pressure ventilation can exacerbate the tension pneumothorax by forcing more air into the pleural space, which can lead to rapid cardiovascular collapse. Addressing the tension pneumothorax with needle decompression or chest tube insertion should be prioritized before considering intubation.

 

Option D. e-FAST (extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma): While e-FAST is a valuable tool in the trauma setting to quickly evaluate for the presence of free fluid (e.g., blood) in the peritoneal, pericardial, or pleural spaces, it may not be the immediate choice when a patient presents with clear signs and symptoms of a tension pneumothorax and is hemodynamically unstable. Immediate intervention to relieve the tension is essential, and while ultrasound can confirm the presence of pneumothorax, in an unstable patient, clinical judgment and prompt action are crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space is the priority to relieve trapped air and stabilize the patient before further interventions.

questions.text: Identify the technique shown in the image: (FMGE JULY 2023
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pringle technique

 

The image shows a surgical technique where the hepato-duodenal ligament is clamped. This procedure is known as the Pringle maneuver or Pringle technique. The Pringle maneuver is used to control intraoperative liver bleeding by clamping the hepatic artery and portal vein, thereby reducing blood flow to the liver. This maneuver is commonly used in cases of liver trauma or during liver resections to minimize blood loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cattel’s technique: This is incorrect because Cattel’s technique is used in IVC injury.

 

Option B. Mattox technique: Mattox technique is done in abnormal aortic injury.

 

Option D. Kocherization: This is incorrect because Kocherization refers to the mobilization of the duodenum to expose structures like the pancreas and is used in procedures such as the Whipple procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pringle maneuver involves clamping the hepatic artery and portal vein to control liver bleeding during surgery, by reducing the inflow of blood to the liver.

choices.text: Lateral edge of pectoralis major muscle
Lateral border of latissimus dorsi muscle

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the triangle of safety for chest tube insertion in a patient with pneumothorax on chest X-ray? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mid-axillary line

 

The mid-axillary line is not a boundary of the triangle of safety. The triangle of safety is defined by specific anatomical landmarks and includes the lateral edge of the pectoralis major muscle, Latissimus dorse, and the fifth intercostal space inferiorly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral edge of pectoralis major muscle: This is the anterior boundary of the triangle of safety.

 

Option C. Base of axilla: This is a boundary of the triangle of safety. It is an important reference point for chest tube insertion to ensure it is performed safely and effectively.

 

Option D. Lateral border of latissimus dorsi muscle: This is a boundary of the triangle of safety. It helps guide the placement of the chest tube in a safe and appropriate location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triangle of safety for chest tube insertion is a surgical landmark used to guide the safe insertion of chest tubes in patients with pneumothorax. The boundaries of the triangle are the lateral edge of the pectoralis major muscle, the lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle, and the 5th intercostal space (ICS) inferiorly, at the level of the nipple above and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle. The base of the triangle is formed by the anterior border of the latissimus dorsi muscle and the lateral edge of the serratus anterior muscle at the base of the axilla.

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a noticeable bulge in his lower abdomen that becomes more pronounced when he's in a standing position. Upon examination, hernia is identified located medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what would be the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

 

  • The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of a direct hernia.
  • Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and are located medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • The appropriate surgical method for the management of a direct hernia is the Lichtenstein mesh repair.
  • The Lichtenstein mesh repair is a tension-free technique that uses a synthetic mesh to reinforce the weakened area of the abdominal wall.
  •  It is the preferred method for direct hernias due to its lower recurrence rates and faster recovery times.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct hernia and Bassini repair: While the Bassini repair is a traditional method of hernia repair, it involves suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches or conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament without using a mesh. This technique is mainly used in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis but has a high recurrence rate compared to mesh repairs.

 

Option C. Indirect hernia and Bassini repair: Incorrect. Indirect hernias are located lateral to the inferior epigastric artery and are managed differently. The Bassini repair, as mentioned, is less commonly used today due to its higher recurrence rates compared to mesh repairs.

 

Option D. Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair: Incorrect. While the Lichtenstein mesh repair can also be used for indirect hernias, the scenario describes a direct hernia based on its location medial to the inferior epigastric artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A direct inguinal hernia is characterized by its location medial to the inferior epigastric artery, and the Lichtenstein mesh repair is the recommended surgical approach due to its efficacy and lower recurrence rates.

questions.text: ASEPSIS wound scoring takes all of the following into consideration except: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Induration

 

ASEPSIS wound score does not take induration into consideration.

 

ASEPSIS wound score and Southampton wound score are used to determine the severity of the surgical site wound infection (SSI).

 

ASEPSIS SCORE

 

 

Criterion Not Included: 

 

Option D. Induration: Induration (hardening of the tissue) is not included in the ASEPSIS wound scoring system. The criteria focus on discharge, erythema, separation of tissues, bacterial isolation, and additional treatments rather than tissue induration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ASEPSIS wound scoring system does not include induration as a criterion. It focuses on factors like purulent and serous discharge, erythema, separation of deep tissue, additional treatments, bacterial isolation, and extended hospital stay to evaluate surgical site infections.

choices.text: SADI-S (Single Anastomosis Duodeno-Ileal Bypass with Sleeve Gastrectomy)

questions.text: Identify the bariatric surgery shown in the image below. (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SADI-S (Single Anastomosis Duodeno-Ileal Bypass with Sleeve Gastrectomy)

 

The image shows SADI-Sleeve (Single Anastomosis Duodeno-Ileal bypass with Sleeve gastrectomy). This procedure combines a sleeve gastrectomy (vertical stomach resection) with a single anastomosis between the duodenum and ileum, creating a duodeno-ileostomy. 

 

The key identifying features are: removal of part of the stomach (sleeve component) and ONE anastomosis connecting the first part of the duodenum to the ileum, bypassing most of the small intestine. The common channel is typically 250-300 cm. 

 

SADI-S is a simplified version of the duodenal switch, maintaining metabolic benefits while reducing surgical complexity by having only one anastomosis instead of two.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sleeve gastrectomy: Incorrect. Sleeve gastrectomy involves only stomach resection without any intestinal bypass or anastomosis. The image clearly shows an intestinal connection which is not present in simple sleeve gastrectomy.

 

Option C. BPD - Biliopancreatic Diversion: Incorrect. BPD is largely obsolete and involves two anastomoses: a gastro-ileostomy and a separate ileo-ileostomy creating a Roux-en-Y configuration. The image shows only one anastomosis at the duodenal level.

 

Option D. DS - Duodenal Switch: Incorrect. Classic duodenal switch involves sleeve gastrectomy with TWO anastomoses: duodeno-ileostomy and a separate jejuno-ileostomy forming a Roux limb. The image shows only a single anastomosis, distinguishing it from DS.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

SADI-Sleeve is identified by the combination of sleeve gastrectomy with a single duodeno-ileal anastomosis, differentiating it from DS (two anastomoses) and simple sleeve gastrectomy (no anastomosis).

questions.text: In triage, immediately life-threatening injury is categorized as what color code? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

In the triage system, which is used to prioritize patients based on the severity of their condition, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code. This indicates that the patient requires immediate medical attention to prevent death or severe complications. The Red category is the highest priority in triage, where intervention is needed within 0 to 6 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green: This color code is used for ambulatory patients with non-life-threatening injuries. These patients are stable and can wait for treatment.

 

Option C. Yellow: The Yellow category is for urgent cases where intervention is required within 6 to 24 hours. While these patients need prompt attention, their condition is not as immediately critical as those in the Red category.

 

Option D. Black: The Black category is reserved for patients who are either deceased or moribund (those who are unlikely to survive). This represents the lowest priority in triage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a triage situation, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code, indicating the need for urgent medical intervention.

questions.text: What sign on day 2 would indicate a need for surgery in a patient who was conservatively managed in the ICU after grade 3 splenic trauma?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumoperitoneum

 

The presence of pneumoperitoneum on imaging would indicate a need for laparotomy as it suggests visceral perforation, which can lead to secondary peritonitis. Conservative management is usually recommended for splenic trauma, and surgical management is reserved for cases of hemodynamic instability or failure to respond to conservative management. Splenic angiography and embolization are also used for non-surgical management. The severity of splenic injury is graded by the AST spleen injury scale, and abdominal CT with intravenous contrast is the preferred investigation. A drop of 1g% of hemoglobin may be a physiological finding, and would not warrant a surgery.

 

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture can be managed with a urinary catheter, while distended gall bladder is a normal finding if patient has been nil per oral.

 

Grades of splenic trauma based on the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) spleen injury scale:

 

 

Pneumoperitoneum, the presence of air in the abdominal cavity, is a concerning sign and typically indicates a perforation of the gastrointestinal tract or another abdominal organ. In a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma, the development of pneumoperitoneum suggests a concomitant hollow viscous perforation and would likely necessitate surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemoglobin falls from 11g% to 10g%: A drop in hemoglobin levels can be indicative of ongoing bleeding but may not be an immediate indication for surgery. It would typically be monitored closely, and the need for surgery would depend on the rate of decline and the overall clinical condition of the patient. Typically, a decline by >2g% Hb is suggestive of active bleed and warrants further management.

 

Option B. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: While extraperitoneal bladder rupture is a serious condition, it is not directly related to splenic trauma. Its management involves keeping a per urethral Foleys and allowing the rupture to heal.

 

Option D. Distended Gall bladder: This is a normal physiological finding and does not mandate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoperitoneum is the most concerning sign in a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma and would indicate a need for surgery, as it suggests a perforation.

questions.text: According to European hernia society classification (EHS), hernia labelled as PL2 implies? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary indirect

 

The European Hernia Society (EHS) classification for groin hernias includes a designation based on the location and whether the hernia is primary or recurrent. 

 

Refers to a primary hernia occurring laterally to the inferior epigastric vessels, which protrudes through the deep inguinal ring. According to the EHS classification, a primary indirect hernia located in the lateral region with defect size 2 finger breadths (3 cm) is labelled as PL2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary direct: Refers to a primary hernia occurring medially to the inferior epigastric vessels, typically in Hesselbach's triangle. It is labelled as “PM”. 2 refers to size of defect as 2 finger breadths (3 cm).

 

Option C. Recurrent direct: Would refer to a recurrence of a hernia in the same place as a previous direct hernia repair.

 

Option D. Recurrent indirect: Would refer to a recurrence of a hernia in the same place as a previous indirect hernia repair.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

According to the EHS classification, a hernia labeled as PL2 refers to a primary indirect inguinal hernia that is having a defect of size 2 finger breadths (3 cm).

questions.text: Most important prognostic factor for Ca Breast is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axillary lymph node status

 

Positive axillary lymph node involvement usually indicates a higher chance of recurrence and a poorer prognosis compared to no lymph node involvement. The number of affected lymph nodes also plays a crucial role in staging the cancer, which directly impacts treatment options and outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Size of the tumor: Generally, the larger the tumor, the worse the prognosis because a larger tumor size often correlates with a more advanced stage of cancer. Tumor size is considered when staging breast cancer, with larger tumors often requiring more aggressive treatment.

 

Option C. Distant metastasis: The presence of distant metastases (stage IV breast cancer) generally indicates a much poorer prognosis because it suggests that the cancer is more aggressive and widespread.

 

Option D. Hormonal status: The hormonal status of the tumor (estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) positive or negative) influences both the prognosis and the treatment options. Hormone receptor-positive tumors are often less aggressive and more likely to respond to hormone therapy compared to hormone receptor-negative tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While all these factors are important in assessing the prognosis of breast cancer, the status of the axillary lymph nodes is traditionally considered a key indicator due to its implications for the spread of the disease within the body and potential treatment strategies.

choices.text: Excellent prognosis is associated with this condition.
Nuclear characteristics are used for identification.
Fine needle aspiration cytology (FAC) is not diagnostic.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with a midline swelling in the neck. Upon examination, cervical node enlargement is also observed. Histopathological analysis of the lesion reveals the following findings Identify the false statement of the following?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fine needle aspiration cytology (FAC) is not diagnostic.

 

  • The histopathological findings provided are indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which includes features such as papillary formation with a fibrovascular stalk, distinct orphan Annie nuclei, and psammoma bodies.
  • Fine needle aspiration cytology is actually a common and reliable diagnostic method for thyroid nodules, including papillary carcinoma.
  • By extracting cells from the thyroid nodule using a fine needle and examining them under a microscope, the presence of characteristic features of papillary carcinoma can be identified.
  •  Thus, the statement suggesting that FNAC is not diagnostic is false

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excellent prognosis is associated with this condition: This statement refers to the typical prognosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Papillary carcinoma, although malignant, is often slow-growing. When detected early and treated appropriately, patients generally have an excellent prognosis with a high survival rate.

 

Option B. It spreads via lymphatics: While papillary carcinoma often spreads via the lymphatics to regional lymph nodes (leading to cervical node enlargement, as seen in the patient), it typically does so at a slow rate. It's important to note that even when there is lymph node involvement, the prognosis still remains relatively favorable compared to other types of thyroid cancers.

 

Option C. Nuclear characteristics are used for identification: The nuclear features of papillary thyroid carcinoma are characteristic and aid in its identification. One such feature is the "orphan Annie eye" nuclei, which are large, empty-appearing nuclei. Other characteristics, like psammoma bodies, can also be present.

 

  • Given the context and the provided image findings indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, FNAC is indeed diagnostic for this condition. Hence, option D is the false statement among the ones provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a reliable and commonly used diagnostic method for thyroid nodules, including papillary carcinoma, as it can identify characteristic histopathological features.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for splenectomy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

 

Bone marrow failure is not an indication for splenectomy because removing the spleen does not address the underlying cause of bone marrow failure. Splenectomy would not provide any benefit in managing or treating bone marrow failure, as the problem lies within the bone marrow's ability to produce blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iatrogenic splenic rupture: This refers to a rupture of the spleen caused inadvertently by medical intervention. In cases of splenic rupture, splenectomy is often necessary to prevent further complications such as internal bleeding.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: Splenectomy can be indicated for thrombocytopenia, particularly if it is caused by conditions like Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP), where the spleen destroys platelets.

 

Option C. Splenic infarct with sepsis: In cases where a splenic infarct leads to sepsis, splenectomy may be necessary to remove the infected spleen and control the spread of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bone marrow failure is not an indication for splenectomy, as the procedure does not address the underlying pathology of bone marrow production issues.

questions.text: A female presents with bleeding per rectum. On digital rectal examination, an ulcerated mass is palpated approximately 6 cm from the anal verge. Biopsy confirms intramucosal carcinoma. Based on this information, what is the correct stage of the rectal carcinoma? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage 0

 

Intramucosal carcinoma of the rectum is classified as carcinoma in situ (Tis) in the TNM staging system. This represents malignant cells confined to the epithelium or invading the lamina propria but not breaching the muscularis mucosae. Since there is no invasion beyond the mucosa, it does not qualify as T1 (which requires submucosal invasion). According to AJCC staging, Tis N0 M0 corresponds to Stage 0, not Stage I. This distinction is critical because intramucosal carcinoma in the colorectum has virtually no risk of lymph node metastasis due to absence of lymphatics in the colonic mucosa, unlike the esophagus where intramucosal carcinoma can metastasize.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: Incorrect. Stage I requires at least T1 disease, which means tumor invasion through the muscularis mucosae into the submucosa. Intramucosal carcinoma does not meet this criterion.

 

Option B. Stage 2A: Incorrect. Stage IIA requires T3 disease (tumor invades through muscularis propria into pericolorectal tissues) with N0 M0, which is far more advanced than intramucosal carcinoma.

 

Option C. Stage 2B: Incorrect. Stage IIB requires T4a disease (tumor penetrates visceral peritoneum) with N0 M0, representing much more advanced disease than carcinoma confined to the mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intramucosal carcinoma of the rectum is classified as carcinoma in situ (Tis), which corresponds to Stage 0 in AJCC staging, not Stage I which requires submucosal invasion.

questions.text: Which of the following positions of the appendix is likely to present with suprapubic pain in a patient with acute appendicitis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Subcaecal

 

Explanation:

 

The subcaecal position is most likely to cause suprapubic pain among the given options. When the appendix is positioned below the cecum, it can extend inferiorly toward the pelvic brim. Inflammation in this position may spread downward, causing irritation to pelvic structures and resulting in suprapubic discomfort. This anatomical relationship explains why subcaecal appendicitis can present with symptoms similar to pelvic appendicitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pre-ileal - When the appendix is anterior to the terminal ileum, it typically presents with classic right iliac fossa pain at McBurney's point, not suprapubic discomfort.

 

Option B. Post-ileal - Post-ileal appendicitis typically causes ill-defined tenderness immediately to the right of the umbilicus and may present with features of diarrhea and retching rather than suprapubic pain.

 

Option D. Retrocecal - The most common position (74%), retrocecal appendicitis typically causes deep tenderness in the loin with possible psoas irritation, manifesting as flank or back pain rather than suprapubic discomfort.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The anatomical positioning of a subcaecal appendix allows for extension toward the pelvic region, making it most likely among the given options to cause suprapubic symptoms when inflamed.

choices.text: Laser ablation can be used for treatment

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with dilated, tortuous veins in the leg. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laser ablation can be used for treatment

 

Explanation:

 

Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA) is an effective minimally invasive treatment for varicose veins

 

  • EVLA works by using laser energy to cause thermal damage to vein wall
  • It has high success rate and faster recovery compared to traditional surgery
  • It is currently the treatment of choice for great saphenous vein varicosities
  • Done under local tumescent anesthesia as daycare procedure

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clinical stage is C6: Incorrect as C6 indicates active venous ulcer. This patient only shows varicose veins which is C2 in CEAP classification (C2S if symptomatic, C2A if asymptomatic)

 

Option C. Sclerotherapy is the first-line treatment: Incorrect as sclerotherapy is primarily used for small reticular veins and telangiectasias, not for large varicose veins

 

Option D. Compression stockings are curative: Incorrect as compression stockings only provide symptomatic relief and don't cure varicose veins. They help manage symptoms but disease continues to progress

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA) is an effective, first-line treatment for symptomatic varicose veins. Compression stockings provide symptom relief but are not curative.

questions.text: What could be the most probable diagnosis for a 26-year-old woman who was brought to the ER at Hospital after a car accident, with a stable blood pressure, a GCS score of 3, and a normal non-contrast CT scan? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diffuse axonal injury

 

The patient's clinical presentation suggests the possibility of diffuse axonal injury, which occurs when the brain experiences shearing forces, often from rotational acceleration within the skull. This can result in damage to the subcortical parasagittal white matter, cerebellum, fornix, and internal and external capsule, leading to disruption of axons and microvasculature.

 

 Automobile accidents are the most common cause of diffuse axonal injury, and patients often remain unconscious from the moment of impact until death. Multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution are typical of diffuse axonal injury, and CT scans may appear normal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), particularly susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI), is the preferred imaging modality for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury, and can reveal small regions of susceptibility artifact or hemorrhage. Subdural hemorrhage, extradural hemorrhage, and cerebral contusion are other potential traumatic brain injuries that can present with different imaging features and may require different treatments.

 

Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is a type of traumatic brain injury that results from the shearing forces during rapid deceleration or rotational head trauma. It can cause profound neurological impairment, even with a seemingly normal CT scan early on. A GCS score of 3 is indicative of severe brain injury, and DAI is a common cause of such a presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdural hemorrhage: Subdural hemorrhage is associated with bleeding between the brain and its outermost covering (the dura mater). While it can result from head trauma, it typically presents with altered mental status, neurological deficits, or focal symptoms. A GCS score of 3 and a normal non-contrast CT scan make this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B. Extradural hemorrhage: It can lead to rapid neurological deterioration, often with a lucid interval after the injury. A normal non-contrast CT scan is inconsistent with an acute extradural hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Cerebral contusion: Cerebral contusions are focal brain injuries characterized by bruising of the brain tissue. They can occur in head trauma and may present with neurological deficits or focal symptoms. However, a normal non-contrast CT scan would typically not rule out a cerebral contusion if it's a small or subtle contusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's presentation with a GCS score of 3 and a normal non-contrast CT scan, the most probable diagnosis is diffuse axonal injury (option C), which can result in severe neurological impairment despite a normal initial CT scan.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a reddish, firm nodule on her chest that has not increased in size. The patient is concerned about the possibility of malignancy and undergoes a biopsy of the lesion. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen shows certain features that aid in the diagnosis. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hemangioma

 

A hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels.

 

The histopathological features of hemangioma include:

 

  • A well-circumscribed lesion composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels.
  • The endothelial cells lining the vessels are flattened and uniform, with minimal mitotic activity.
  • The vessels are often arranged in lobules, with stromal cells separating the lobules.
  • The stromal cells are composed of fibroblasts, myofibroblasts, and/or pericytes.

 

In cases of cavernous hemangiomas, the vessels are larger and more dilated than those in capillary hemangiomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoma: A lipoma is a benign tumor of adipose (fat) tissue and typically presents as a soft, rubbery lump that can be moved with slight finger pressure. On histopathology, a lipoma will show mature fat cells that are uniform in size. They don't exhibit much cellular variability, and there are no vascular proliferations like those seen in a hemangioma.

 

Option B. Fibroadenoma: Fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor. It's composed of glandular and fibrous tissue. On physical examination, it often feels like a small, rubbery lump that moves around easily within the breast tissue. Histologically, fibroadenomas show a combination of glandular breast tissue and stromal tissue. They are not typically found on the chest but rather within the breast tissue itself, and their histological appearance would not match the vascular features of a hemangioma.

 

Option C. Nevus: A nevus, commonly referred to as a mole, is a benign skin lesion that contains nevomelanocytes. Nevus cells can be found in the epidermis, dermis, or both. Histologically, it would show nests of melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction, and/or in the dermis, depending on the type of nevus. It wouldn't have the vascular structures seen in a hemangioma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels, characterized histologically by well-circumscribed lesions composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels arranged in lobules.

questions.text: Identify the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess and arteriotomy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 11

 

The blade shown in the image is number 11 blade used for skin incisions (E.g., Incision and Drainage) and Arteriotomy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

11 number blade is used In stab incisions needed when lancing an abscess or inserting a chest drain and in skin incisions and arteriotomy

choices.text: Injury to base of skull - CSF Otorrhea
